title: 107_hr1338
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. ASSISTANT SECRETARY OF STATE FOR VICTIMS OF INTERNATIONAL TERRORISM." is about the establishment of a new position within the State Department to focus on assisting victims of international terrorism. The Secretary of State will designate an Assistant Secretary of State for Victims of International Terrorism, who will have specified duties and relationships within the Department of State as outlined in a directive to be issued within 30 days of the enactment of the Act. The Assistant Secretary of State for Victims of International Terrorism will oversee all matters related to American victims of international terrorism and efforts to bring terrorists to justice, participating in interagency groups as necessary. The Assistant Secretary of State for Victims of International Terrorism will participate in interagency groups within the executive branch, including those related to international terrorism and counter-terrorism, to assess policies affecting Americans abroad. The Secretary of State or Undersecretary of State for Arms Control and International Security may exempt certain groups from this requirement. The Assistant Secretary of State may be exempted from attending certain interagency groups if it is not in the national security interests of the United States. The Assistant Secretary of State may be exempted from attending certain interagency groups if it is not in the national security interests of the United States. The Assistant Secretary shall be the principal policy community representative to the criminal justice community on international terrorism affecting Americans abroad and shall have reporting responsibilities within the Department of State. The Assistant Secretary of State is responsible for the report required by section 2 and other reports on international terrorism affecting Americans abroad prepared by the Department of State. The Secretary of State must provide an annual report to Congress on international terrorism affecting Americans abroad, including the number of Americans impacted, efforts to obtain justice for victims, a list of known terrorists, and recommendations for bringing terrorists to justice in the United States.
